subject: meta-aspeed: otp: create otp image
commitMessage:
meta-aspeed: otp: create otp image

1. Add otptool.bbclass to create otp image.
2. Update u-boot recipe to "inherit otptool.bbclass" for
otp image creation in the u-boot tasks.
3. Update socsec tool for SPL and OTP image verification if
verify failed u-boot should be built failed.
4. Use OE logging utilities.

Signed-off-by: Jamin Lin <jamin_lin@aspeedtech.com>
Change-Id: I0ba5da4d112b49d182bdf2751614afe62850eac3

Ah, sorry, this somehow dropped off my review list. I'll take a look shortly.

Jamin: Let's drop the A1/A2 components for the purpose of this patch. Let's just support the 2600 from A3 onwards.

It would be helpful if we could detect OTP configurations for A1/A2 and exit with an error message, but I'm not going to require it to submit what you've got here. With this we can start adding OTP configs to the tree, and that's a benefit for at least us at IBM. We might need some extra support from otptool to help with the error case (maybe a `--no-pre-production flag that makes otptool error out for pre-production configs?)

Hi Andrew
Got it. I will update patch to only support AST2600 A3 secure boot.

Can I modify otptool.bbclass to check user Json config?
For example: otptoo.bbclass load JSON file and parser tha value of "version" property.
If the version is not A3, breaks the build and shows error message.


A3:
https://github.com/AspeedTech-BMC/openbmc/blob/aspeed-master/meta-aspeed-sdk/recipes-aspeed/security/aspeed-secure-config/configs/ast2600/security/otp/evbA3_RSA4096_SHA512.json#L3  
A1:
https://github.com/AspeedTech-BMC/openbmc/blob/aspeed-master/meta-aspeed-sdk/recipes-aspeed/security/aspeed-secure-config/configs/ast2600/security/otp/evbA1_RSA2048_SHA256.json#L3

I think it can be changed as below.
```
DEPENDS += '${@oe.utils.conditional("SOCSEC_SIGN_ENABLE", "1", " socsec-native otp-data-native", "", d)}'
```
I don't understand.  There is an OTPTOOL_ENABLE and an SOCSEC_SIGN_ENABLE?  What do they do?  Why are they separate?  Where are we documenting them?

I noticed OpenBMC added "SOSSEC_SIGN_ENABLE" to make user enable/disable RoT SPL creation, please see socsec-sign.bbclass.
By default, disables RoT SPL creation.
If user want to create RoT SPL, user need to set this variable in platform configurations.
Take p10bmc platform for example:
https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/blob/master/meta-ibm/conf/machine/p10bmc.conf#L56
If "SOCSEC_SIGN_ENABLE" is "1", build process will create RoT SPL.
So, I used this variable to disable/enable otp image creation.
But you have a separate variable OTPTOOL_ENABLE used only on line 8 to control dependencies?  I don't understand this.  Should this have been SOCSEC_SIGN_ENABLE?

Yeah, I think this is at least confused. Either we use SOCSEC_SIGN_ENABLE on line 8 for consistency, or we use OTPTOOL_ENABLE here.

I'm not sure I like the idea of conflating SOCSEC_SIGN_ENABLE with generating the OTP image, but I'm happy for someone to say something convincing about it. If we split the behaviours then I suspect in reality most systems will set both variables to the same value.

Hi Andrew and Patrick
Thanks for your review and suggestion.

I will replace OTPTOOL_ENABLE with SOCSEC_SIGN_ENABLE in otptool.bbclass.

Is this a native recipe or a target recipe?  If it is native-only, it should be named 'otp-data-native'.  If it is native and target (which I don't understand why it would be) then you should also BBCLASSEXTEND = "nativesdk".
It can be native and nativesdk packages. This recipe is used for install otp patch files to make otptool(u-boot recipe) access these patch file in Yocto at build time.
So you need to specify it as nativesdk also.  Having one without the other is likely wrong.

Hi Patrick
According to you and IBM(Andrew and Joel) decsision, openbmc will only enavble secure boot for AST2600 A3.
So, this recipe will be removed.
Thanks for your review.

If users use AST2600 A1, we suggest they use these patch to fix secure boot issue.
For example:
1. Add "otp-data-native" in u-boot dependency.
2. Set OTPTOOL_USER_DATA ?= "${STAGING_DIR_NATIVE}${datadir}/otp-data/2600" in u-boot
The patch data will be installed into sysroot-native/usr/share/otp-data/2600 directory by "otp-data-native package".
3. Add platform Json config to uses these patch data to create otp image
https://github.com/AspeedTech-BMC/openbmc/blob/aspeed-master/meta-aspeed-sdk/recipes-aspeed/security/aspeed-secure-config/configs/ast2600/security/otp/evbA1_RSA4096_SHA512.json#L12 

```
"user_data": [
            {
                // dw_hex
                // bin
                "types": "dw_hex",
                "file": "rsa4096_patch.hex",
                "offset": "0x1B80"
            }
```
4. otptool create otp image with Json file

```
otptool make_otp_image \
            --key_folder ${OTPTOOL_KEY_DIR} \
            --user_data_folder ${OTPTOOL_USER_DATA} \
            ${OTPTOOL_CONFIG}
```

The otptool will find these patch data in ${STAGING_DIR_NATIVE}${datadir}/otp-data/2600

```

Where is all this documented?  How is anyone expected to figure this out?

Are these keys something that Aspeed generated?  Are these example keys?  How does someone put their own keys in here?
This is a ROM code patch. These are hex representations of the instructions that will be patched in. The patch data (instructions) gets configured into the OTP.

That makes it seem even crazier.  Can't we supply an asm file at least then?

So we are patching the ROM based on which algorithm we want to use for our keys?  Again, I don't know how we plan to document this as there is almost no words in this commit.

It certainly would be good to have more information about what's going on here, but I expect even with more information we'd be hard-pressed to make much sense of it without the context of the ROM code in full.

> So we are patching the ROM based on which algorithm we want to use for our keys?

The bug is fixed in the A3 ROM code. No patch is required for A3, which is the mass production revision. A1 and A2 are pre-production. It's unfortunate, but I'd guess that Aspeed would prefer they didn't have the bugs either :)

We could limit support to A3 in the OpenBMC tree (and Aspeed carry patches for A1/A2 in their SDK fork?). We're already considering this on a separate socsec change where the endianness of the keys in the OTP changes to big-endian on A3 (from litte-endian on A1 and A2).

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/49788

> Again, I don't know how we plan to document this as there is almost no words in this commit.

Yes, some more words would be good, or reference to Aspeed documentation on the matter.

Oh, yeah, if all this is to work around bugs in A1/A2 parts and A3 doesn't need patching, then let's just forget about it?  Is anyone working on OpenBMC requesting upstream support of secure boot on A1/A2 parts?  I don't think we (Meta / Facebook) are.
We (IBM) have decided we will not be deploying secure-boot on our A1/A2-based systems, only A3.

Hi Andrew
Thanks for your explantioan.
Yes, these data are ROM code patch for AST2600 A1 secure boot controller.
AST2600 A3 do not need to use these data file.
I respect you(IBM) and Patrick decision,so the ROM code patch for AST2600 A1 will be reomoved in this sumbit.

By teh way, if users want to support A1, they can download these data in ASPEED forked OpenBMC,  https://github.com/AspeedTech-BMC/openbmc
And do some changes for A1 support.

Hi Andrew, Joel and Patrick
Updated new patch.
Waiting for review.
Thanks-Jamin

All,

p10bmc enabled socsec to sign SPL and created otp image.
However, p10bmc did not provide otp config file, so built failed.

please CI build log for detail, https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-openbmc/8789/distro=ubuntu,label=docker-builder,target=p10bmc/console
I'll put up a patch that integrates our OTP config.

Thanks Andrew

As for checking A1/A2 otp config, can I modify "otptool.bbclass" to support it?
For example:
otptool.bbclass load OTP JSON config and parser it.
Then, check the AST2600 version. If version is none A3, breaks the build and showes error message.

I'd prefer we don't do that, honestly. The recipe shouldn't have knowledge of implementation details like that. I'd prefer we add a command-line option to otptool along the lines of what I suggested previously.

Are there issues preventing us from that approach?

All,
The p10bmc machine build successfully with Andrew OTP config. Thanks for your help.
However, bletchley build failed. The reason is this machine enabled to sign SPL but did not provide OTP config and failed to create OTP image.
Could you please help to check this issue?
By the way, due to my Chinese New Year holiday, I will be back at office on February 7.
Thanks-Jamin
```
22:40:22 ERROR: u-boot-aspeed-sdk-1_v2019.04+gitAUTOINC+a570745a1a-r0 do_deploy: ExecutionError('/home/jenkins-op/workspace/ci-openbmc/distro/ubuntu/label/docker-builder/target/bletchley/build/work/bletchley-openbmc-linux-gnueabi/u-boot-aspeed-sdk/1_v2019.04+gitAUTOINC+a570745a1a-r0/temp/run.do_deploy.163812', 1, None, None)

Thanks Andrew

Added "otp print otp-all.image" in otptool.bbclass to show the detail information of the creating OTP image.

Hi Andrew,
Could you please tell me how to do "submit together" to fix this CI build issue?
Thanks-Jamin
Some minor style review points. The patch looks good otherwise.

nit: creation

You can also make this a bbwarn:

bbwarn "OTP creation is only supported on AST2600 boards"

instead of echo and then exit, can use bbfatal:

bbfatal "Invalid otptool config: ${OTPTOOL_CONFIG}"

and it will display this as an error, and return for you
Arguably redundant, as the first thing we do in create_otp is check this variable again.

Joel and Andrew
Change to use OE logging utilities
Ready for review.
Thanks-Jamin

Hi Andrew and Joel
I need your help to do "submit together" to fix CI build failed issue.
Or could you please tell me how to do it?
Thanks-Jamin

> Hi Andrew and Joel
> I need your help to do "submit together" to fix CI build failed issue.
> Or could you please tell me how to do it?

What do you need to submit together?

Hi Joel
Andrew hlped me fix this issue.
CI build should include the following change. Otherwise, p10bmc build failed because this machine enabled to sign SPL but did not provide OTP config.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/50914
LGTM. To be merged once the meta-ibm patches have landed
I've submitted the p10bmc change. This should be rebased on top of that, and then we can submit.
